body.p: Abrasives and polishing removes layers of surface deformation and exposes the material structure for analysis.

ul.li: Polishing should be performed for the minimum amount of time required to achieve the desired results.
After collecting a glass cube sample, see the following:

ol.li:
Use the Buehler
EcoMet 30 Manual Single Grinder Polisher.

PPE Required: Cut resistant gloves.
Gather the tools and equipment needed for polishing.
Polisher machine
Grinder pads
Microcloth pad
Pad removal stick
Cerium solution

Select the best sample for the polishing and color measurements.
Taken on the same day and time.

PPE Required: Cut resistant gloves.
Use the grinder stone and water.
Remove any sharp edges from the top of the glass cube sample.

Start with course pads and follow with finer pad.
Finish with the micro cloth pad and cerium solution for the final glow.
Coarse to fine DGD pads:
Green 240 µm
Black 125 µm
Red 75 µm
Yellow 35 µm
White 15 µm
Blue 8 µm
Micro-cloth PSA pad
Note: Ineffective polishing can cause excessive scratching, comet tails, relief, smearing, edge rounding, and embedding.
These issues can lead to inaccurate readings and results.
Place the DGD pad on the polisher plate.

Turn on the polisher.
The On-Off switch is located in the back of the equipment.

Turn the Power Switch to On to start the plate spinning.
Select the RPM (300 RPM recommended).
Switch the water to Active.
Note: Water should be active when using the DSD pads.
If final polishing, see step 14.

PPE Required: Cut resistant gloves for Green 240 µm pads.
Hold the glass sample firmly from the top and side surfaces.
Place the sample on the moving pad, close to the center.
Hold the sample. Maintain the same pressure.
Move the sample from the center to the edge of the pad in the transversal direction of the plate movement.
Repeat the movement 10 times.
Rotate the sample 90° and repeat the grinding movement 10 times.
Repeat the movement set 2 additional times to evenly grind the surface of the sample.
Note: Use special care so that the sample does not escape from your hands or stumble with the pad.

entry.p: PPE Required: Cut resistant gloves for Green 240 µm pads.

li.p: Turn over the glass sample to the opposite surface and repeat step 10.

ul.li: Use both hands to hold the sample and apply even pressure to the surfaces.

li.p: The sample should be polished at least on both surfaces of the lager dimensions.

ul.li: It is recommended for the light from the spectrophotometer to pass through the larger dimensions of the sample. Both polished faces should be flat and perpendicular to the light.

ol.li:
When the polish is finished:
Set the sample aside.
Turn off the water switch.
Let the pad rinse for a couple of seconds and turn off the power switch.

Use the pad removal stick to remove the pad.
Dry the pad and set it aside.
Change the finer grade.
Repeat steps 9-12.
Note: Use the removal stick to reduce the likelihood of damaging the pad.

li.p: Exchange the last DGD pad (blue 8 µm) with the PSA Microcloth pad.

ul.li: Add cerium solution to the pad.

li.p: Polish the glass sample as in steps 10-11.

ul.li: Apply additional pressure to the sample while polishing.
Repeat the final polish on the desired surfaces.

note.p: Note: Use special care so that the sample does not escape from your hands or stumble with the pad cloth.

ol.li:
The cloth should be visibly wet without casting off when rotating.
Maintain the cerium solution throughout the polishing cycle.
Too little causes heat damage, reduces polishing, and damages the pad.
Too much causes hydroplaning, reduces polishing, and wastes abrasive.

Rinse the sample and verify that it has the correct polish.
Repeat polishing if needed.

Rinse the PSA Microcloth pad after polishing.
Dry the pad.
Properly store all DGD and PSA Microcloth pads.
Continue to Consumables.
